paragraphs.body: The Lost Scrolls is a series of canonical books written and illustrated by various authors. The information contained in the books (aside from the introductions) was collected by each book's respective authors and from ${link_0} screenplays.
paragraphs.text: The Lost Scrolls is a series of canonical books written and illustrated by various authors. The information contained in the books (aside from the introductions) was collected by each book's respective authors and from Avatar: The Last Airbender screenplays.

paragraphs.body: The book series frequently has poor kerning, with some words appearing as though they have spaces between each letter. There are also numerous sentences and fragments in which words do not appear to have been spaced at all, resulting in sentences looking like single words.
paragraphs.text: The book series frequently has poor kerning, with some words appearing as though they have spaces between each letter. There are also numerous sentences and fragments in which words do not appear to have been spaced at all, resulting in sentences looking like single words.

paragraphs.body: On page twenty-two of The Lost Scrolls Collection, a sentence reads, "All he ever wanted was to do was protect us," with an excess "was".
paragraphs.text: On page twenty-two of The Lost Scrolls Collection, a sentence reads, "All he ever wanted was to do was protect us," with an excess "was".

paragraphs.body:
Page seventy of The Lost Scrolls Collection, the epilogue of Water, has a sentence that reads, "Prince Zuko of the Fire Nation is considered an outcast by his father, the Fire lord," rendering the "Lord" in "${link_0}" a common noun, which it is not.
 This capitalization error is repeated throughout The Lost Scrolls in general: pages 132, 146, 147, 149, 177, 192, and 194 of The Lost Scrolls Collection make the mistake. Furthermore, page 194 says both "Fire Lord" and "Fire lord", correctly and incorrectly.
paragraphs.text:
Page seventy of The Lost Scrolls Collection, the epilogue of Water, has a sentence that reads, "Prince Zuko of the Fire Nation is considered an outcast by his father, the Fire lord," rendering the "Lord" in "Fire Lord" a common noun, which it is not.
 This capitalization error is repeated throughout The Lost Scrolls in general: pages 132, 146, 147, 149, 177, 192, and 194 of The Lost Scrolls Collection make the mistake. Furthermore, page 194 says both "Fire Lord" and "Fire lord", correctly and incorrectly.

paragraphs.body: This capitalization error is repeated throughout The Lost Scrolls in general: pages 132, 146, 147, 149, 177, 192, and 194 of The Lost Scrolls Collection make the mistake. Furthermore, page 194 says both "Fire Lord" and "Fire lord", correctly and incorrectly.
paragraphs.text: This capitalization error is repeated throughout The Lost Scrolls in general: pages 132, 146, 147, 149, 177, 192, and 194 of The Lost Scrolls Collection make the mistake. Furthermore, page 194 says both "Fire Lord" and "Fire lord", correctly and incorrectly.

paragraphs.body: Page eighty-nine of The Lost Scrolls Collection reads, "The Kingdom's capital, Ba Sing Se, is led by the Earth king and is the largest of all Earth Kingdom cities." There are two errors in this sentence: The sentence makes the single word "kingdom" a proper noun; however, without specification in concern to which kingdom it refers, the word is a common noun. Further, it renders the "King" in "${link_0}" a common noun, which it is not, in a similar fashion to the capitalization of "Fire Lord" in The Lost Scrolls: Water.
paragraphs.text: Page eighty-nine of The Lost Scrolls Collection reads, "The Kingdom's capital, Ba Sing Se, is led by the Earth king and is the largest of all Earth Kingdom cities." There are two errors in this sentence: The sentence makes the single word "kingdom" a proper noun; however, without specification in concern to which kingdom it refers, the word is a common noun. Further, it renders the "King" in "Earth King" a common noun, which it is not, in a similar fashion to the capitalization of "Fire Lord" in The Lost Scrolls: Water.

paragraphs.body: On the same page as above, the book makes mention of "the village of ${link_0}", referencing ${link_1}; "village" should be capitalized as it refers to a specific village (e.g. "The City of Philadelphia" traditionally has "City" capitalized as it refers to the city specifically).
paragraphs.text: On the same page as above, the book makes mention of "the village of Kyoshi", referencing Kyoshi Island; "village" should be capitalized as it refers to a specific village (e.g. "The City of Philadelphia" traditionally has "City" capitalized as it refers to the city specifically).

paragraphs.body: Page ninety-one of The Lost Scrolls Collection says that ${link_0} is "an algaelike mass", making "algae-like" one word instead of hyphenating it.
paragraphs.text: Page ninety-one of The Lost Scrolls Collection says that creeping slime is "an algaelike mass", making "algae-like" one word instead of hyphenating it.

paragraphs.body: The Lost Scrolls page 113 reads, "${link_0} ${link_1} [...] taught the fighting and defensive techniques now used by the Kyoshi warriors", without capitalizing "warriors".
paragraphs.text: The Lost Scrolls page 113 reads, "Avatar Kyoshi [...] taught the fighting and defensive techniques now used by the Kyoshi warriors", without capitalizing "warriors".

paragraphs.body:
On page 134 of The Lost Scrolls Collection the "Based on screenplays by" notice spells "Bryan Konietzko" as "Brian Konietzko", with an "I" in place of a "Y".
 Ironically, the very next credit on the screenplay notice is "John O'Bryan", spelled correctly with a "Y".
 This same mistake and its irony is repeated on the credit page of The Lost Scrolls: Air.
paragraphs.text:

 Ironically, the very next credit on the screenplay notice is "John O'Bryan", spelled correctly with a "Y".
 This same mistake and its irony is repeated on the credit page of The Lost Scrolls: Air.

paragraphs.body: Page 177 of The Lost Scrolls Collection spells "${link_0}" as "Air temple", with a capital "A". This same capitalization error occurs on the next page, regarding the phrase "Fire temple".
paragraphs.text: Page 177 of The Lost Scrolls Collection spells "air temple" as "Air temple", with a capital "A". This same capitalization error occurs on the next page, regarding the phrase "Fire temple".

paragraphs.body: On page 193 of The Lost Scrolls Collection a sentence reads, "Before he retired, [${link_0}'s] army led a siege on ${link_1}, the great ${link_2} capital for six hundred days." In this sentence, the second clause should have the words "the great Earth Kingdom capital" enclosed by commas as an appositive phrase.
paragraphs.text: On page 193 of The Lost Scrolls Collection a sentence reads, "Before he retired, [Iroh's] army led a siege on Ba Sing Se, the great Earth Kingdom capital for six hundred days." In this sentence, the second clause should have the words "the great Earth Kingdom capital" enclosed by commas as an appositive phrase.

paragraphs.body: Page 251 of The Lost Scrolls Collection states the ${link_0} has a thin red scar around his eye. In the show, however, this "scar" was actually the edging of his monocle.
paragraphs.text: Page 251 of The Lost Scrolls Collection states the mechanist has a thin red scar around his eye. In the show, however, this "scar" was actually the edging of his monocle.

paragraphs.body: On page 255 of The Lost Scrolls Collection, "${link_0}" is spelled "Warballoon".
paragraphs.text: On page 255 of The Lost Scrolls Collection, "war balloon" is spelled "Warballoon".
